items.title: User_id and ImplicitGrantHandler
items.body:
This is not a bug report. It is a request to help understand correct usage of the library.

When the access_token object is created in the ImplicitGrant flow:
https://github.com/wndhydrnt/python-oauth2/blob/v1/oauth2/grant.py#L698
the user_id is not captured/populated.

I thought that when my API server receives a bearer token, I would be able to query the token store and use the user_id field of the returned AccessToken data to populate the REMOTE_USER request variable.

In my python-oauth2 server I have been able to add the user_id (which I capture at the authenticate step) as "additional data". But it puzzled me (I am not an expert in this area) that the AccessToken class has a field for user_id which is not used when instantiation occurs in the ImplicitGrant flow.

items.title: cannot use POST to confirm
items.body:
The docs include this example:

```python
# Create a SiteAdapter to interact with the user.
# This can be used to display confirmation dialogs and the like.
class ExampleSiteAdapter(oauth2.web.AuthorizationCodeGrantSiteAdapter,
                         oauth2.web.ImplicitGrantSiteAdapter):
    def authenticate(self, request, environ, scopes, client):
        # Check if the user has granted access
        if request.post_param("confirm") == "confirm":
            return {}

        raise oauth2.error.UserNotAuthenticated

    def render_auth_page(self, request, response, environ, scopes, client):
        response.body = '''
<html>
    <body>
        <form method="POST" name="confirmation_form">
            <input type="submit" name="confirm" value="confirm" />
            <input type="submit" name="deny" value="deny" />
        </form>
    </body>
</html>'''
        return response
```

which suggests that you can use POST to the authorize URL to set the confirm/deny state. This does not work right now because the AuthorizationCodeGrant explicitly checks if the method is GET before dispatching to the AuthorizationCodeAuthHandler, so it will always fail with:

```json
{
"error": "unsupported_response_type",
"error_description": "Grant not supported"
}
```

To reproduce the error, run the example on the front page of [the docs](http://python-oauth2.readthedocs.io/en/latest/).

items.title: URI decoding and encoding modifies state variable
items.body:
We have a client who's sending us a state variable of the form "https%3a%2f%2f...".  This is legal as far as I can tell.  But if it's URI-decoded and then re-encoded (which is how oauth2 works now), then the python urllib2.quote function encodes it to "https%3a//...".   

That is a valid URI-encoding, but the oauth2 documentation says that "The authorization server must return the unmodified state value back to the application."  

The central problem is that URI-decoding and then URI-encoding a string is not an identity function, because there are multiple valid encodings of the same string.

I believe the only way to preserve the unmodified state value is twofold:
1. The oauth2 server must never URI-decode the state variable that the client passes in (once decoded, there's no way to recover which encoded form the client passed in).
2. The oauth2 library therefore should not URI-encode the state variable in grant.py (definitely in _generate_location, and also in _redirect_access_token I believe but I haven't tested the latter).

Obviously this change could break a lot of existing implementations that use URI-decoded variables, so it should probably be a flag/setting of some sort.  

Right now I'm monkey-patching _generate_location to work around this.

items.title: Invalid authorization url causes crash on python3
items.body:
There appears to be a bug in wsgi.py here it returns str from Application __init__ if the request URL does not match authorize_url or token_url.  bytes is expected by wsgiref, and this throws an exception in the server in python3 (encountered with python 3.5.2).  This issue can cause crashes in production for anyone using python3, but I do not think it is exploitable.

Suggested patch:

diff -ur python-oauth2-master.orig/oauth2/web/wsgi.py python-oauth2-master/oauth2/web/wsgi.py
--- python-oauth2-master.orig/oauth2/web/wsgi.py	2017-09-26 23:20:48.970931215 -0400
+++ python-oauth2-master/oauth2/web/wsgi.py	2017-09-26 23:21:29.437250033 -0400
@@ -102,7 +102,7 @@
             and env["PATH_INFO"] != self.token_uri):
             start_response("404 Not Found",
                            [('Content-type', 'text/html')])
-            return ["Not Found"]
+            return [b"Not Found"]
 
         request = self.request_class(env)
 
PS. I hope version 2.0 is released soon - I would have a need for the token_generator data argument right now (it seems to have been added some time ago).

items.title: Returned state token not url-encoded
items.body:
Current implementation reads state from request query parameter with request.get_param(), which handles url-decoding automatically. When state is written back to a redirect url it is not url-encoded. This causes state mismatch in client. Only applies to clients that use state strings that yield are url-decodable.

Reproducable with /examples/authorization_code_grant.py, modifying ClientApplication.

Generate a state token in client:

```
def _request_auth_token(self):
        print("Requesting authorization token...")
        auth_endpoint = self.api_server_url + "/authorize"
        self.state = "123123%25"
        query = urllib.urlencode({"client_id": "abc",
                                  "redirect_uri": self.callback_url,
                                  "response_type": "code",
                                  "state":self.state,
                                  })

        location = "%s?%s" % (auth_endpoint, query)
```

And check state when receiving token:

```
def _read_auth_token(self, env):
    print("Receiving authorization token...")

    query_params = urlparse.parse_qs(env["QUERY_STRING"])
    self.auth_token = query_params["code"][0]

    if self.state and self.state != query_params["state"][0]:
        raise Exception("Received auth token with invalid state. If this was a browser, CSRF")
```

Fix by url-encoding the state when applying it to redirect urls.
/oauth2/grant.py

```
469      query += "&state=" + quote(self.state)

708      uri_with_fragment += "&state=" + quote(self.state)
```

items.title: Authenticate a client via Authorization field in header
items.body:
[Section 2.3](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-2.3) recommends authenticating a client using HTTP Basic Auth.
As sending client credentials within the request body is the only method currently implemented, HTTP Basic Auth should be implemented.

items.title: Provider does not handle some exceptions
items.body: Exceptions like those raised by classes contained in `oauth2.store` are not handled by `oauth2.Provider`. This leads to the server responding with `500 Server Error` HTTP error instead of an `4xx` HTTP error.

items.title: Set headers to prevent responses from being cached
items.body:
Section [5.1](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-5.1) of RFC 6749 states:

> The authorization server MUST include the HTTP "Cache-Control"
> response header field [RFC2616] with a value of "no-store" in any
> response containing tokens, credentials, or other sensitive
> information, as well as the "Pragma" response header field [RFC2616]
> with a value of "no-cache".

These headers need to be added to responses.

items.title: Scope is never returned to a client
items.body:
Sections [3.3](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-3.3) and [5.1](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-5.1) of RFC 6749 both define that a scope may be returned to a client. It even has to be returned if the requested scope is different from the granted scope.

The implementation of the Authorization Code Grant returns the scope as part of the response to a authorization code request, which is wrong. It must return the scope as part of the access token response.

items.title: Add support for scopes
items.body:
Scopes are defined in [section 3.3](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-3.3) of RFC 6749.

A scope can be used in
- Authorization Code Grant
- Implicit Grant
- Resource Owner Password Credentials Grant
